I remember that when we have two groups, and we want to find out how much they overlap, we can use the principle of inclusion-exclusion. The formula for the union of two sets A and B is:

\[

\text{A or B} = \text{A} + \text{B} - \text{A and B}

\]

In this case, A is the set of people who have cats, and B is the set of people who have dogs.

So, if 30% have cats and 40% have dogs, then the percentage of people who have either cats or dogs would be 30% + 40% - the percentage who have both.
